sections.title: What are we comparing?
sections.content:
Past simple (I went, she finished) talks about a finished time in the past. Present perfect (I have been, she has finished) links the past to now – no specific past time, or the result is still relevant.

The choice often depends on time words: yesterday, last week, in 2019 → past simple. Ever, never, just, yet, already, since, for (with present meaning) → often present perfect.

sections.title: When we use Past Simple
sections.content:
Use the past simple when:

• The time is finished and stated or clear: I saw him yesterday. She left in 2020.
• We ask when something happened: When did you go? What time did it start?
• We tell a story or sequence of past events: I got up, had breakfast, and left.

Typical time expressions: yesterday, last week/month/year, ago, in 2019, when I was young.

sections.title: When we use Present Perfect
sections.content:
Use the present perfect when:

• The exact time is not important or not said: I've been to Japan. She's lost her keys.
• The result or situation is still relevant now: I've broken my phone (it's still broken).
• We talk about life experience: Have you ever tried sushi?
• With for/since (duration up to now): I've lived here for five years.

Typical time expressions: ever, never, just, already, yet, for, since, so far, up to now.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• Finished past time (yesterday, last week, in 2019, when?) → Past simple (did, went, saw).
• Past linked to now, no specific time, or result still true → Present perfect (have/has + past participle).
• Don't use present perfect with a finished past time expression (wrong: I have seen him yesterday).

sections.title: Typical Czech learner errors
sections.content:
Czech has one past tense; English has past simple and present perfect. Czech learners often:

• Use past simple with 'ever', 'never', 'yet', 'already' (life experience or 'up to now'): Wrong: I never saw him. Did you ever go to Paris? Right: I've never seen him. Have you ever been to Paris?
• Use present perfect with a finished time: Wrong: I have seen him yesterday. When have you left? Right: I saw him yesterday. When did you leave?
• Use present perfect when asking 'when?': Wrong: When have you been to London? Right: When did you go to London? (When? → past simple)
• Use past simple with for/since when the situation continues now: Wrong: I lived here since 2020. Right: I've lived here since 2020.

Tip: Yesterday, ago, last week, in 2019, when? → past simple. Ever, never, just, yet, already, for, since (until now) → present perfect.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
questions.explanation: Yesterday is a finished past time → past simple.

questions.question: We want to ask about life experience (no specific time). Which is natural?

options.a: Did you ever go to Paris?
options.b: Do you ever go to Paris?
options.c: Have you ever been to Paris?

questions.question: She moved here in 2020 and still lives here. Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Since + duration up to now → present perfect.

questions.question: We want to know when something happened. Which is natural?

gapfill.title: Practice: Gap fill (Past simple vs Present perfect)

questions.question: I ____ (see) that film last week.
answers: saw
questions.explanation: Last week = finished past time → past simple.

questions.question: She ____ (live) in London for three years. (She still lives there.)
answers: has lived
questions.explanation: For + duration up to now → present perfect.

questions.question: ____ you ever ____ (be) to Japan?
answers: have you ever been

questions.question: They ____ (go) home an hour ago.
answers: went
questions.explanation: Ago = finished past time → past simple.

questions.question: I ____ (just / finish) my homework.
answers: have just finished
have just finished my homework

questions.question: When ____ you ____ (start) learning English?
answers: did you start

errorcorrection.title: Practice: Error correction (Past simple vs Present perfect)

questions.question: Wrong: 'I have been to the cinema yesterday.' Correct the sentence.
answers: i went to the cinema yesterday
I went to the cinema yesterday.
I went to the cinema yesterday

questions.question: Wrong: 'She has left last month.' Correct the sentence.
answers: she left last month
She left last month.
She left last month

questions.question: Wrong: 'Did you ever try Indian food?' (asking about life experience) Correct the sentence.
answers: have you ever tried indian food
Have you ever tried Indian food?
Have you ever tried Indian food

makesentence.title: Practice: Making sentences (Past simple vs Present perfect)

answers: I saw the film last week.
I saw a film last week.

questions.prompt: she / live / here / five years (still lives here)
answers: She has lived here for five years.
She's lived here for five years.
questions.explanation: Duration up to now → present perfect.

answers: I have ever been to New York.
Have you ever been to New York?
I have been to New York.
I've been to New York.
questions.explanation: Life experience: 'I have been to New York' or 'Have you ever been to New York?' – accepting first person.

answers: They have just arrived.
They've just arrived.

makequestion.title: Practice: Making questions (Past simple vs Present perfect)

answers: When did you start your job?
When did you start the job?
Have they ever been to Australia?
Have they ever been to Australia
How long has she had the car?
How long has she had her car?
questions.explanation: How long (duration up to now) → present perfect.
